author: HCAndersen
text: A DUCK once arrived from Portugal, but there were some who said she came from Spain, which is almost the same thing.

author: HCAndersen
text: At all events, she was called the "Portuguese," and she laid eggs, was killed, and cooked, and there was an end of her.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the ducklings which crept forth from the eggs were also called "Portuguese," and about that there may be some question.

author: HCAndersen
text: But of all the family one only remained in the duckyard, which may be called a farmyard, as the chickens were admitted, and the cock strutted about in a very hostile manner.

author: HCAndersen
text: "He annoys me with his loud crowing," said the Portuguese duck; "but, still, he's a handsome bird, there's no denying that, although he's not a drake.

author: HCAndersen
text: He ought to moderate his voice, like those little birds who are singing in the lime-trees over there in our neighbor's garden, but that is an art only acquired in polite society.

author: HCAndersen
text: How sweetly they sing there; it is quite a pleasure to listen to them!

author: HCAndersen
text: I call it Portuguese singing.

author: HCAndersen
text: If I had only such a little singing-bird, I'd be kind and good as a mother to him, for it's in my nature, in my Portuguese blood."

author: HCAndersen
text: While she was speaking, one of the little singing-birds came tumbling head over heels from the roof into the yard.

author: HCAndersen
text: The cat was after him, but he had escaped from her with a broken wing, and so came tumbling into the yard.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That's just like the cat, she's a villain," said the Portuguese duck.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I remember her ways when I had children of my own.

author: HCAndersen
text: How can such a creature be allowed to live, and wander about upon the roofs.

author: HCAndersen
text: I don't think they allow such things in Portugal."

author: HCAndersen
text: She pitied the little singing-bird, and so did all the other ducks who were not Portuguese.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Poor little creature!" they said, one after another, as they came up.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We can't sing, certainly; but we have a sounding-board, or something of the kind, within us; we can feel that, though we don't talk about it."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But I can talk," said the Portuguese duck; "and I'll do something for the little fellow; it's my duty;" and she stepped into the water-trough, and beat her wings upon the water so strongly that the bird was nearly drowned by a shower-bath; but the duck meant it kindly.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is a good deed," she said; "I hope the others will take example by it."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Tweet, tweet!" said the little bird, for one of his wings being broken, he found it difficult to shake himself; but he quite understood that the bath was meant kindly, and he said, "You are very kind-hearted, madam;" but he did not wish for a second bath.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I have never thought about my heart," replied the Portuguese duck, "but I know that I love all my fellow-creatures, except the cat, and nobody can expect me to love her, for she ate up two of my ducklings.

author: HCAndersen
text: But pray make yourself at home; it is easy to make one's self comfortable.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am myself from a foreign country, as you may see by my feathery dress.

author: HCAndersen
text: My drake is a native of these parts; he's not of my race; but I am not proud on that account.

author: HCAndersen
text: If any one here can understand you, I may say positively I am that person."

author: HCAndersen
text: "She's quite full of 'Portulak,'" said a little common duck, who was witty.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the common ducks considered the word "Portulak" a good joke, for it sounded like Portugal.

author: HCAndersen
text: They nudged each other, and said, "Quack! that was witty!"

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the other ducks began to notice the little bird.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The Portuguese had certainly a great flow of language," they said to the little bird.

author: HCAndersen
text: "For our part we don't care to fill our beaks with such long words, but we sympathize with you quite as much.

author: HCAndersen
text: If we don't do anything else, we can walk about with you everywhere, and we think that is the best thing we can do."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You have a lovely voice," said one of the eldest ducks; "it must be great satisfaction to you to be able to give so much pleasure as you do.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am certainly no judge of your singing so I keep my beak shut, which is better than talking nonsense, as others do."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Don't plague him so, interposed the Portuguese duck; "he requires rest and nursing.

author: HCAndersen
text: My little singing-bird do you wish me to prepare another bath for you?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, no! no! pray let me dry," implored the little bird.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The water-cure is the only remedy for me, when I am not well," said the Portuguese.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Amusement, too, is very beneficial.

author: HCAndersen
text: The fowls from the neighborhood will soon be here to pay you a visit.

author: HCAndersen
text: There are two Cochin Chinese amongst them; they wear feathers on their legs, and are well educated.

author: HCAndersen
text: They have been brought from a great distance, and consequently I treat them with greater respect than I do the others."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the fowls arrived, and the cock was polite enough to-day to keep from being rude.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You are a real songster," he said, "you do as much with your little voice as it is possible to do; but there requires more noise and shrillness in any one who wishes it to be known who he is."

author: HCAndersen
text: The two Chinese were quite enchanted with the appearance of the singing-bird.

author: HCAndersen
text: His feathers had been much ruffled by his bath, so that he seemed to them quite like a tiny Chinese fowl.

author: HCAndersen
text: "He's charming," they said to each other, and began a conversation with him in whispers, using the most aristocratic Chinese dialect: "We are of the same race as yourself," they said.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The ducks, even the Portuguese, are all aquatic birds, as you must have noticed.

author: HCAndersen
text: You do not know us yet,- very few know us, or give themselves the trouble to make our acquaintance, not even any of the fowls, though we are born to occupy a higher grade in society than most of them.

author: HCAndersen
text: But that does not disturb us, we quietly go on in our own way among the rest, whose ideas are certainly not ours; for we look at the bright side of things, and only speak what is good, although that is sometimes very difficult to find where none exists.

author: HCAndersen
text: Except ourselves and the cock there is not one in the yard who can be called talented or polite.

author: HCAndersen
text: It cannot even be said of the ducks, and we warn you, little bird, not to trust that one yonder, with the short tail feathers, for she is cunning; that curiously marked one, with the crooked stripes on her wings, is a mischief-maker, and never lets any one have the last word, though she is always in the wrong.

author: HCAndersen
text: That fat duck yonder speaks evil of every one, and that is against our principles.

author: HCAndersen
text: If we have nothing good to tell, we close our beaks.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Portuguese is the only one who has had any education, and with whom we can associate, but she is passionate, and talks too much about 'Portugal.'"

author: HCAndersen
text: "I wonder what those two Chinese are whispering about," whispered one duck to another; "they are always doing it, and it annoys me.

author: HCAndersen
text: We never speak to them."

author: HCAndersen
text: Now the drake came up, and he thought the little singing-bird was a sparrow.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, I don't understand the difference," he said; "it appears to me all the same.

author: HCAndersen
text: He's only a plaything, and if people will have playthings, why let them, I say."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Don't take any notice of what he says," whispered the Portuguese; "he's very well in matters of business, and with him business is placed before everything.

author: HCAndersen
text: But now I shall lie down and have a little rest.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is a duty we owe to ourselves that we may be nice and fat when we come to be embalmed with sage and onions and apples."

author: HCAndersen
text: So she laid herself down in the sun and winked with one eye; she had a very comfortable place, and felt so comfortable that she fell asleep.

author: HCAndersen
text: The little singing-bird busied himself for some time with his broken wing, and at last he lay down, too, quite close to his protectress.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sun shone warm and bright, and he found out that it was a very good place.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the fowls of the neighborhood were all awake, and, to tell the truth, they had paid a visit to the duckyard, simply and solely to find food for themselves.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Chinese were the first to leave, and the other fowls soon followed them.

author: HCAndersen
text: The witty little duck said of the Portuguese, that the old lady was getting quite a "doting ducky," All the other ducks laughed at this.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Doting ducky," they whispered.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, that's too 'witty!'"

author: HCAndersen
text: And then they repeated the former joke about "Portulak," and declared it was most amusing.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then they all lay down to have a nap.

author: HCAndersen
text: They had been lying asleep for some time, when suddenly something was thrown into the yard for them to eat.

author: HCAndersen
text: It came down with such a bang, that the whole company started up and clapped their wings.

author: HCAndersen
text: The Portuguese awoke too, and rushed over to the other side: in so doing she trod upon the little singing-bird.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Tweet," he cried; "you trod very hard upon me, madam."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Well, then, why do you lie in my way?" she retorted, "you must not be so touchy.

author: HCAndersen
text: I have nerves of my own, but I do not cry 'tweet.'"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Don't be angry," said the little bird; "the 'tweet' slipped out of my beak unawares."

author: HCAndersen
text: The Portuguese did not listen to him, but began eating as fast as she could, and made a good meal.

author: HCAndersen
text: When she had finished, she lay down again, and the little bird, who wished to be amiable, began to sing,-

author: HCAndersen
text: "Chirp and twitter, The dew-drops glitter, In the hours of sunny spring, I'll sing my best, Till I go to rest, With my head behind my wing."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now I want rest after my dinner," said the Portuguese; "you must conform to the rules of the house while you are here.

author: HCAndersen
text: I want to sleep now."

author: HCAndersen
text: The little bird was quite taken aback, for he meant it kindly.

author: HCAndersen
text: When madam awoke afterwards, there he stood before her with a little corn he had found, and laid it at her feet; but as she had not slept well, she was naturally in a bad temper.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Give that to a chicken," she said, "and don't be always standing in my way."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Why are you angry with me?" replied the little singing-bird, "what have I done?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Done!" repeated the Portuguese duck, "your mode of expressing yourself is not very polite.

author: HCAndersen
text: I must call your attention to that fact."

author: HCAndersen
text: "It was sunshine here yesterday," said the little bird, "but to-day it is cloudy and the air is close."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You know very little about the weather, I fancy," she retorted, "the day is not over yet.

author: HCAndersen
text: Don't stand there, looking so stupid."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But you are looking at me just as the wicked eyes looked when I fell into the yard yesterday."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Impertinent creature!" exclaimed the Portuguese duck: "would you compare me with the cat- that beast of prey?

author: HCAndersen
text: There's not a drop of malicious blood in me.

author: HCAndersen
text: I've taken your part, and now I'll teach you better manners."

author: HCAndersen
text: So saying, she made a bite at the little singing-bird's head, and he fell dead on the ground.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now whatever is the meaning of this?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "she said; "could he not bear even such a little peck as I gave him?

author: HCAndersen
text: Then certainly he was not made for this world.

author: HCAndersen
text: I've been like a mother to him, I know that, for I've a good heart."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the cock from the neighboring yard stuck his head in, and crowed with steam-engine power.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You'll kill me with your crowing," she cried, "it's all your fault.

author: HCAndersen
text: He's lost his life, and I'm very near losing mine."

author: HCAndersen
text: "There's not much of him lying there," observed the cock.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Speak of him with respect," said the Portuguese duck, "for he had manners and education, and he could sing.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was affectionate and gentle, and that is as rare a quality in animals as in those who call themselves human beings."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then all the ducks came crowding round the little dead bird.

author: HCAndersen
text: Ducks have strong passions, whether they feel envy or pity.

author: HCAndersen
text: There was nothing to envy here, so they all showed a great deal of pity, even the two Chinese.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We shall never have another singing-bird again amongst us; he was almost a Chinese," they whispered, and then they wept with such a noisy, clucking sound, that all the other fowls clucked too, but the ducks went about with redder eyes afterwards.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We have hearts of our own," they said, "nobody can deny that."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Hearts!" repeated the Portuguese, "indeed you have, almost as tender as the ducks in Portugal."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Let us think of getting something to satisfy our hunger," said the drake, that's the most important business.

author: HCAndersen
text: If one of our toys is broken, why we have plenty more."
